<|endoftext|>// Out of vector of strings, return the longest one. Return the first one in case of multiple
// strings of the same length. Return None in case the input vector is empty.
// >>> longest({})
// 
// >>> longest({"a", "b", "c"})
// "a"
// >>> longest({"a", "bb", "ccc"})
// "ccc"
// #include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string longest(vector<string> strings){
    string out;
    string longest;
    for(int i = 0; i < strings.size(); i++){
        if(strings[i].length() > longest.length()){
            longest = strings[i];
        }
    }
    if(longest.length() > 0){
        for(int i = 0; i < strings.size(); i++){
            if(strings[i].length() == longest.length()){
                out = strings[i];
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    return out;
}

The length of the vector will be in the range of {1, 1000}. // 2. The elements in the vector will be in the range of {-1000, 1000}. // 3. 0 <= k <= len(arr) // #include #include #include using namespace std; vector max_k_numbers(vector arr, int k) { vector ans; sort(arr.begin(), arr.end()); ans.reserve(arr.size()); int n = arr.size(); int m = k - 1; int i = 1; while (i <= n) { if (arr[i] > arr[m]) { ans.push_back(arr[i]); i++; } else { ans.push_back(arr[m]); m--; } } return ans; } int main() { int t; cin >> t; while (t--) { int n; cin >> n; vector arr; for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { cin >> arr[i]; } vector ans = max_k_numbers(arr, n); cout << ans.size() << endl; } return 0; } <|/ a tags=c++,algorithm,sorting |> <| c |> I didn't downvote, but I suspect that this is an answer to the question asked in the title. <|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long special_factorial(int n){
    long long fact=1,bfact=1;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
    {
        bfact=bfact*i;
        fact=fact*i;
    }
    return fact;
}

#include<string>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<int> even_odd_count(int num){
    vector<int> even_odd_count(num);
    int i;
    for(i=1;i<=num;i++){
        if(num%2==0){
            even_odd_count[i]++;
        }
    }
    return even_odd_count;
}

// and return it in lowercase.
// Restrictions: 1 <= num <= 1000
// 
// Examples:
// >>> int_to_mini_roman(19) == "xix"
// >>> int_to_mini_roman(152) == "clii"
// >>> int_to_mini_roman(426) == "cdxxvi"
// #include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string int_to_mini_romank(int number){
    string current="";
    vector<string> rep={"m","cm","d","cd","c","xc","l","xl","x","ix","v","iv","i"};
    vector<int> num={1000,900,500,400,100,90,50,40,10,9,5,4,1};
    int pos=0;
    while(number>0)
    {
        number=number/10;
        current=rep[number%10];
        pos++;
    }
    if(pos>0)
    {
        for(int i=0;i<pos;i++)
        {
            current=current+rep[i];
        }
    }
    return current;
}

<|endoftext|>// Filter given vector of any python values only for integers
// >>> filter_integers({"a", 3.14, 5})
// {5}
// >>> filter_integers({1, 2, 3, "abc", {}, {}})
// {1, 2, 3}
// #include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
#include<boost/any.hpp>
#include<list>
typedef std::list<boost::any> list_any;
using namespace std;
vector<int> filter_integers(list_any values){
    list_any::iterator it;
    for(it=values.begin();it!=values.end();it++){
        if(boost::any_cast<int>(*it)){
            values.erase(it);
        }
    }
    return values;
}

<|endoftext|>// Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that start with a given prefix.
// >>> filter_by_prefix({}, "a")
// {}
// >>> filter_by_prefix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
// {"abc", "vector"}
// #include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> filter_by_prefix(vector<string> strings, string prefix){
    vector<string> filtered;
    for(string s : strings){
        if(s.substr(0, prefix.length()) == prefix){
            filtered.push_back(s);
        }
    }
    return filtered;
}

<|endoftext|>// Circular shift the digits of the integer x, shift the digits right by shift
// and return the result as a string.
// If shift > number of digits, return digits reversed.
// >>> circular_shift(12, 1)
// "21"
// >>> circular_shift(12, 2)
// "12"
// #include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string circular_shift(int x,int shift){
    string xs;
    xs=to_string(x);
    if (xs.length()<shift)
        xs.insert(0,"0");
    xs.insert(0,"0");
    for (int i=0;i<xs.length()-shift;i++){
        xs.insert(i+shift,xs[i]);
    }
    return xs;
}
int main(){
    cout<<"Enter the number to be shifted: ";
    int n;
    cin>>n;
